THE SETTING -- Crane & Company Paper Makers in Rockefeller Center, where among the wooden racks of stationery and rows of inkpens on Wednesday afternoon sat Ms. Demeanor, otherwise known as Mary M. Mitchell, a columnist for The Philadelphia Inquirer and author of several mannerly manuals, including her latest, ''The Complete Idiot's Guide to Etiquette.''

She was hoping to convert people into readers and dispense the advice that has made her a name in the etiquette game. She and her hero, Letitia Baldrige, are writing a book together. The table of contents alone is 37 pages.
THE BUZZ -- So is it good etiquette to call someone an idiot?
''You know, I caught a lot of heat from my friends about that,'' Ms. Mitchell said, chuckling. ''But I just told them it's we who call ourselves idiots.''

She was referring to the embarrassed disclaimers the suited professionals and sunburned tourists used at her book-signing table. Questions often began: ''I should know this, but'' or ''I feel so silly asking this, but'' or ''I can never remember what to do when.'' Ms. Mitchell reassured them.

Manners are a mixture of common sense and kindness, she said, but etiquette is simply a list of rules to be learned. At least 20 questions here were about thank-you notes, their necessity, timing and wording. She believes in the handwritten note.
But times are changing, and so long as one has good manners, she says, one can forgo etiquette now and then. But some still want a definite ruling.
A couple approached. ''We're getting married,'' said Ken Whitacre of Florida, his fiancee, Kerri Jenkins, at his side. ''So, who is supposed to pay for the wedding band?''
Ms. Mitchell, standing because she said she felt awkward sitting, said: ''Well, traditionally, you would buy each other's. You buy hers and she buys yours.''
Mr. Whitacre asked, ''But what if I want to pay for both?''
Ms. Mitchell paused, then looked over at Ms. Jenkins. ''Why would you ever say no?''
Ms. Jenkins: ''I don't think he is supposed to do that. It's not his job.''
Ms. Mitchell: ''Sometimes it's hard to say thank you to big gifts, and you don't want to start the marriage one-sided.''
They nodded eagerly. She is good.
She turned to Mr. Whitacre. ''Just buy her another ring next year,'' she said. ''Let her get this one.''
Ms. Jenkins was so relieved she gave a little hop. ''Oh, we like her! We like her!''
Gooey grins all around, and the happy pair was out the door. Ms. Mitchell may sit down now.
KELLY CROW
NEIGHBORHOOD REPORT: ROCKEFELLER CENTER -- BUZZ
